content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure where to start, but I’m here because my wife thought it might help. Things have been really hard at home lately—my son is struggling, my wife and I are arguing more, and honestly, I’m feeling stuck and overwhelmed. I don’t even know if this will change anything.

It sounds like there’s been a lot on your plate lately, and it’s left you feeling stuck and overwhelmed. It’s not always easy to open up about these things, but you’ve taken a big step by being here today. What’s been weighing on you the most right now?

I think the hardest part is my son. He’s been acting out so much, and I feel like no matter what my wife and I try, nothing is working. It’s putting so much strain on everything—our marriage, my ability to focus at work, even my relationship with my daughter. I feel like I’m failing as a parent.

It sounds like you’re carrying a heavy weight right now, trying your best to support your son while also balancing so many other parts of your life. Feeling like you're struggling as a parent can be incredibly tough, especially when it’s impacting your family and other relationships. What does it feel like when you’re in those moments with him, when you’re trying to figure out what to do?

In those moments, it feels like nothing I do or say makes any difference. It’s frustrating, and I feel helpless. I want to help him, but I have no idea how to reach him, and it just ends in me losing my temper or shutting down completely. It's getting harder to even try.

It sounds like you’re in such a painful place—wanting so much to help your son but feeling like your efforts aren’t making a difference. That frustration and helplessness seem to be building to a point where it’s hard to keep going. It’s clear how much you care about your son, even when things feel overwhelming. What do you think might help you reconnect or feel less stuck in those moments?
It’s really hard to say. Honestly, I’m not sure anything would help. I’ve tried so many things, and nothing seems to work. I feel like I’m at a loss, like I’ve run out of options.

It sounds like you’ve been trying so hard, and it’s exhausting to feel like none of it is helping. You’re doing the best you can in an incredibly challenging situation, even when it feels like the options have run out. What keeps you going when it feels this hard?

I guess what keeps me going is that I still want to help my son. No matter how difficult it gets, I want to see him happy and doing better. And honestly, I want to keep my family together—for my wife, my daughter, and for myself too. I just feel like I’m losing my grip on how to do that.

It’s clear how deeply you love your family and how much you want to see your son happy and your family thriving. Even in the middle of such a tough time, your commitment to them keeps you moving forward. That takes a lot of strength. What would it mean to you and your family if you could start to feel more in control again?

It would mean everything. If I could feel like I’m actually helping my son and keeping my family together... it would be a relief. But honestly, it feels so far out of reach right now that I don’t even know where to start.

That longing for relief and for things to feel more manageable is powerful—it shows how much you care and how much this means to you. Even though it feels far out of reach, you’re here today and open to talking about it, which is a meaningful step. What do you think is the biggest barrier keeping you from feeling like you could start moving toward that relief?

I think the biggest barrier is that I feel stuck, like I’ve run out of ideas and don’t know where to turn. My son’s behavior feels out of control, and I don’t feel equipped to handle it. It’s hard to see a clear path forward, and that makes it feel overwhelming to even try.

Feeling stuck like that can make everything seem overwhelming, especially when it feels like the way forward isn’t clear. You’ve been trying so hard to find a way to help, even when it feels like you don’t have the tools you need. What would it mean to you to feel more supported or to have a bit more direction in handling things with your son?

It would mean a lot, I think. If I didn’t feel so lost, maybe I could handle things better and actually help my son. I just don’t know where to find that kind of support or if it would even make a difference. That doubt makes it hard to take the first step.

Doubt can be so paralyzing, especially when you’re already feeling lost and overwhelmed. But it sounds like having support and direction could give you some hope and make things feel more manageable. If taking a first step were possible, what kind of support do you think would feel most helpful to you right now?

Maybe having someone guide me—someone who actually understands what might be going on with my son and can help me figure out how to support him better. I feel like I need tools or a plan because what we’ve been doing hasn’t worked. But even the idea of reaching out for that kind of help feels intimidating.

Reaching out for help can feel like a big and overwhelming step, especially when things have been so challenging already. Still, recognizing that having guidance and tools might make a difference is a really meaningful insight. It shows your willingness to find a way to move forward for your son and your family. What would make that first step of reaching out feel just a little more doable for you?

Reaching out is intimidating, but maybe if I knew where to start or had a recommendation, it wouldn’t feel so overwhelming. I guess I might feel more comfortable if my wife or someone I trust could help me figure out who to talk to. It just feels like a lot to do alone.

It makes sense that taking on this step by yourself would feel like too much right now. Having support from someone you trust, like your wife, to help you find the right resources or connections could take some of that weight off your shoulders. It sounds like involving her—or even starting with a small conversation together—might help this feel less overwhelming. What do you think about the idea of talking it through with her?
